revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name= Ki-34 |image= Nakajima AT-2.jpg |caption= Nakajima AT-2, civil version of the Ki-34 }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type= Civil [[airliner]]/Light [[military transport aircraft]] |manufacturer= [[Nakajima Aircraft Company]] |designer= |first flight= 12 September 1936 |introduced= [[1937 in aviation|1937]] |retired= |status= |primary user= [[Imperial Japanese Army Air Force|IJA Air Force]] |more users= [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service|IJN Air Service]]
[[Imperial Japanese Airways|''Dai Nippon Koku KK'']]
[[Manchukuo National Airways]] |produced= |number built= 351 |unit cost= |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Nakajima Ki-34''' was a Japanese light transport of [[World War II]]. It was a twin-engine, low-wing [[monoplane]]; the [[Landing gear|undercarriage]] was of [[tailwheel]] type with retractable main units. During the [[Pacific War]], the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] assigned the type the [[World War II Allied names for Japanese aircraft|reporting name]] '''Thora'''. ==Design and development== The Ki-34 was originally designed as a civil transport. Nakajima Aircraft Company, which had the license-production rights to the [[Douglas DC-2]], began design work in 1935 on a smaller twin engine [[airliner]] for routes which did not have the capacity to justify use of the larger DC-2. The initial design was designated '''AT-1''', and after numerous design iterations, flew as a [[prototype]] designated '''AT-2''' on 12 September 1936.{{Harvnb|Francillon|1979|p=204.}} The design was all metal, except for the [[flight control surface]]s, which were [[plywood]]. The wings used a multi-cell [[Cantilever#In aircraft|cantilever]] design. The prototype was fitted with {{convert|432|kW|hp|-1|abbr=on}} [[Nakajima Kotobuki]] 2-1 [[radial engine]]s with fixed pitch wooden [[propeller (aircraft)|propeller]]s, which were replaced in production models with Kotobuki-41 {{convert|529|kW|hp|-1|abbr=on}} nine-cylinder [[radial engine]]s, with [[Controllable pitch propeller|variable pitch]] metal propellers. ==Operational history== ===Civil use (AT-2)=== A total of 32 AT-2s were produced for [[Imperial Japanese Airways]] (''Dai Nippon Koku KK'') and [[Manchukuo National Airways]],{{Harvnb|Francillon|1979|p=205.}} operating on scheduled routes between [[Tokyo]] and [[Hsinking]], Tokyo and [[Tianjin]], and within [[Manchukuo]]. These aircraft remained in operational service until the [[surrender of Japan]] in August 1945. ===Military history (Ki-34 and L1N1)=== With a high demand for increased [[Military transport aircraft|military transport]] capability after the start of the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] in 1937, the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] adapted the AT-2 design for military use by fitting with more powerful Nakajima Ha-1b radial engines and re-designating the aircraft as the '''Army Type 97 Transport''' and '''Ki-34'''. The initial 19 aircraft were produced by Nakajima Aircraft, and another 299 aircraft were subsequently produced by the Army-affiliated [[Tachikawa Aircraft Company Ltd|Tachikawa Hikoki K.K.]]. The final [[airframe]] was delivered in 1942. In operational service, the Ki-34 was used as a [[utility aircraft]] for [[Liaison aircraft|liaison]] and communications duties, and for [[paratrooper]] training and [[Special Forces]] operations. At a later date, some aircraft were transferred to the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]], where they were known as the '''Navy Type AT-2 Transport''' or '''Nakajima L1N1'''. Several were also transferred to the air force of the Japanese [[puppet state]] of [[Cochinchina]] in 1942. ==Operators== ===Military operators=== ;{{flag|Japan}} * [[Imperial Japanese Army Air Force]] * [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] ===Civil operators=== ;{{flag|Japan}} * [[Imperial Japanese Airways]] (''Dai Nippon Koku KK'') ;{{flag|Manchukuo}} * [[Manchukuo National Airways]] ;{{flag|Mongolia}} *[[Mongolian People's Army|Mongolian People's Army Aviation]]-Captured and operated more than 12 aircraft since in late September 1945 ==Specifications (Ki-34)== {{aircraft specifications |plane or copter?= plane |jet or prop?= prop |ref=''Japanese Aircraft of the Pacific War''; ''Warbirds Resource Group''{{cite web|url=http://www.warbirdsresourcegroup.org/IJARG/nakajimaki34.html|title=Warbirds Resource Group|last=|first=|date=2010-08-24|work=Nakajima Ki-34/L1N1 "Thora"|publisher=}} |crew= 3 |capacity= 8 passengers |length main= 15.30 m |length alt= 59 ft 2.25 in |span main= 19.81 m |span alt= 65 ft |height main= 4.15 m |height alt= 13 ft 7.5 in |area main= 49.2 m² |area alt= 529.6 ft² |airfoil= |empty weight main= 3,500 kg |empty weight alt= 7,716 lb |loaded weight main= 5,250 kg |loaded weight alt= 11,574 lb |useful load main= |useful load alt= |max takeoff weight main= |max takeoff weight alt= |more general= |engine (prop)= [[Nakajima Kotobuki]] 2-1 |type of prop= nine cylinder, air-cooled [[radial engine]] |number of props= 2 |power main= 529 kW |power alt= 710 hp |power original= |max speed main= 360 km/h |max speed alt= 194 kn, 224 mph |cruise speed main= 310 km/h |cruise speed alt= 167 kn, 193 mph |stall speed main= |stall speed alt= |never exceed speed main= |never exceed speed alt= |range main= 1,200 km |range alt= 648 nmi, 746 mi |ceiling main= 7,000 m |ceiling alt= 22,965 ft |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main= 106.7 kg/m² |loading alt= 21.9 lb/ft² |thrust/weight= |power/mass main= |power/mass alt= |more performance= |armament=none |avionics= }} {{aircontent |related= |similar aircraft= |lists= |see also= }} ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * Francillon, Ph.D>, René J. ''Japanese Aircraft of the Pacific War''. London: Putnam & Company Ltd., 1979. ISBN 0-370-30251-6. *{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Stuart|year=1999|title=Airliners of the World|publisher=Australian Aviation|isbn=1-875671-44-7}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category|Nakajima AT-2/Ki-34/L1N1}} * [http://www.warbirdsresourcegroup.org/IJARG/nakajimaki34.html Warbirds Resource Group] {{Nakajima aircraft}} {{Japanese Army Aircraft Designation System}} {{Allied reporting names}} [[Category:Japanese military transport aircraft 1930–1939|Ki-34, Nakajima]] [[Category:Japanese airliners 1930–1939|Ki-34, Nakajima]] [[Category:Nakajima aircraft|Ki-034]]
